work.p: This manuscript is a partial draft of "Memorial in Behalf of a Freer Municipal Government, and Against Sunday Restrictions," a public letter to the Brooklyn Common Council and Mayor. The letter was printed in the Brooklyn Star on October 20, 1854.

titleStmt.title: just as much here directly
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript is a partial draft of "Memorial in Behalf of a Freer Municipal Government, and Against Sunday Restrictions," a public letter printed in the Brooklyn Star on October 20, 1854. Whitman probably drafted the manuscript shortly before the piece was published.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: I admire a beautiful woman
bibl.orgName: The Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature, New York Public Library
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
Three draft lines of poetry are written on the back of the manuscript.

body.ab: exemplify them just as will much here directly at our doors, or the corners of our streets curbstones, or in our City Hall.—

After all is said, however, the work of establishing and raising the character of cities of course remains at last in their original capacity with the people themselves.—Strictly proper Perhaps the citizens
